prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RN88 and RN122 Band 6 and 7 12CO and 13CO and continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Lines 12CO and 13CO 3-2 BW 234.375 MHz Continuum 2GHz at 331.6 GHz Single point, no ACA

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
RN 88 APEX 13CO (2-1) peak antenna temperature is 0.35K. Assuming a 5" disk with a uniform temperature and allowing for beam dilution this corresponds to 4.7K. the required 0.35K rms allows this line to be detected with a high S/N. The temperature is probably not uniform over the disk so the maximum S/N will be even higher. RN88 CO 3-2 APEX peak antenna temperature is 0.6K so this line will be detected with a even higher S.N ratio. The RN122 APEX CO and 13CO (3-2) antenna temperatures are higher than those of RN88 and thus also the expected S/N is higher.
The continuum intensity is not known and the possible detection will be a bonus.

The channelwidth is sufficiently small to resolve the line even if its width in a single pixel is only half of the width (0.9km/s) observed with APEX. Averaging spectrometer channels is requested to lower the data rate.

Optical (wideband and Halpha) and NIR (J, H, Ks, Paschen Beta, H2 1-0 S(1) 2.14 micron) imaging shows that globulette 88 is is a 5" to 6" diameter compact and round globule without an extended low density gas/dust halo. The requested 0.8" spatial resolution is sufficient to resolve the expected source structure.
Besides a similar core as RN88 RN122 has a lower density (less obscuration in Halpha and Paschen beta images)tail. The CO blue-shifted emission in Fig. 2 is seen CO 2-1 line. If the RN 122 structure is similar to that of RN40 analysed in Gahm et al 2013 (IRAM 30m CO (2-1), (1-0) mapping and APEX CO (3-2), (2-1) spectra compared) the CO 3-2 emission is likely to come from the globulette head. Thus the tail will be observed only in CO 2-1 (i.e. ACA observations included).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RN88 Band6 12co 2-1, 13co 2-1, C18O 2-1 and continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: RN88 Band6 CO, 13CO and C18O 2-1 BW 117.188MHz Continuum 233 GHz BW 1.9GHz single point, no ACA

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: APEX 13CO 2-1 peak antenna temperature is 0.35K. Assuming a 5" disk with a uniform temperature and allowing for beam dilution this corresponds to 4.5K. If C18O 2-1 line is optically thin the required 0.3K rms allows also this line to be detected with a S/N of approximately 3. The temperature is probably not uniform over the disk so the maximum S/N will be even higher. The 12CO 2-1 APEX peak antenna temperature is 0.6K so this line will be detected with a high S.N ratio. The continuum intensity is not known and the possible detection will be a bonus.

The channelwidth is sufficiently small to resolve the line even if its width in a single pixel is only half of the width (1.0km/s) observed with APEX. Averaging four spectrometer channels is requested.

Optical (wideband and Halpha) and NIR (J, H, Ks, Paschen Beta, H2 1-0 S(1) 2.14 micron) imaging shows that the source is a 5" to 6" diameter compact and round globule without an extended low density gas/dust halo. The requested 0.8" spatial resolution is sufficient to resolve the expected source structure.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RN122 band 6 CO 2-1, 13CO 2-1, C18O 2-1 and continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: RN122 band 6 CO 2-1 and 13CO 2-1 BW 117 continuum 233 GHz, BW 1875 MHz ACA included

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
APEX 13co 2-1 peak antenna temperature is 0.6K. Assuming a 6" disk with a uniform temperature and beam dilution this corresponds to 17K. Assuming C18O 2-1 is optically thin the required 0.4K rms allows also this line to be detected with a good S/N The temperature is probably not uniform over the disk so the maximum S/N will be even higher. The 12CO 2-1 APEX peak antenna temperature is 0.9K so this line will be detected with a high S.N ratio.
The three 12CO (2-1) velocity components in RN122 are not expected to coincide spatially. The main velocity component comes from the compact head and the two blueshifted components from the tail. Their respective sizes are expected to be smaller than 11", the largest detectable structure of the 12m array at his frequency.
We want to observe the three CO (2-1) isotopoloques (12CO, 13CO and C18O) simultaneously with a 0.1 km/s velocity resolution (the APEX line width is 0.9 km/s). The data rate has been lowered by adding up channels. However, the narrowest band widths for 13CO and 13CO can not be chosen as according to OT the bands would end up at a noisy part of the reciever. The data rate given by OT with the selected setup is however 6.79 MB/s exceeding slightly the average data rate of 6MB/s.
The intensity of the possible continuum emission is not known and its detection would be a bonus.

The channelwidth is sufficiently small to resolve the line even if its width in a single pixel is only half of the width (1.0km/s) observed with APEX. Averaging spectrometer channels is requested to lower the data rate.

Besides the 6" compact core RN122 has a lower density (less absorption in Halpha and Paschen beta images). The CO blue-shifted emission in Fig. 2 is seen CO 2-1 line. If the RN 122 structure is similar to that of RN40 analysed in Gahm et al 2013 (IRAM 30m CO (2-1), (1-0) mapping and APEX CO (3-2), (2-1) spectra compared) the blueshifted CO (2-1)emission is likely to come from the globulette tail. Thus the tail will be observed in CO 2-1 (i.e. ACA observations included). The requested angular resolution is sufficient to resolve the expected source structure.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RN88 and RN122 CS(3-2),C34S(3-2), H2CO, continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Globulettes RN88 and RN122 single pointing CS(3-2) 146.969GH BW 58.594 MHz C34S(3-2) 144.617GHz, BW 58.594 MHz H2CO 2-1) 145.602GHz 58.594 MHz continuum 146.0GHz, BW 1875 MHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The selected resolution is just sufficient to resolve the line. Averaging spectrometer channels is requested to lower the data rate.

Optical (wideband and Halpha) and NIR (J, H, Ks, Paschen Beta, H2 1-0 S(1) 2.14 micron) imaging shows that the source is a 5" to 6" diameter compact and round globule without an extended low density gas/dust halo. The requested 0.8" spatial resolution is sufficient to resolve the expected source structure.

The CS (3-2) line antenna temperature observed in Rosette Nebula RN40 (Gonzalez-Alfonso and Cernicharo 1994, APJ 430,L125) at IRAM 30m (HPBW ~17") is 0.17K. Taking into account the beam filling the filling corrected line should be >1.6K. If the line is of the simlar intensity in the dense core of RN88 and RN122 the expected line in a 1" ALMA beam will be detected with sufficient S/N.
We have no estimate for the intensities of other lines which are to observed bsides CS (2-1) and their possible detection will be a bonus. The 146GHz continuum is necessary because of calibration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RN88 and RN122 CS(2-1), C34S(2-1), H13CO+(1-0), Continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Globulettes RN88 and RN122 single pointing CS(2-1) 97.98095GHz, 58.594 MHz C34S(2-1) 96.12.95GHz, BW 58.594 MHz H13CO+(1-0) 86.75249GHz BW 58.594 MHz continuum 85.2GHz, BW 1875 MHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The selected resolution is just sufficient to resolve the line. Averaging spectrometer channels is requested to lower the data rate.

Optical (wideband and Halpha) and NIR (J, H, Ks, Paschen Beta, H2 1-0 S(1) 2.14 micron) imaging shows that globulettes RN88 and RN122 have a 5" to 7" diameter compact and round opaque cores. The requested 0.8" spatial resolution is sufficient to resolve the expected core structure.

The CS (2-1) line antenna temperature observed in Rosette Nebula RN40 (Gonzalez-Alfonso and Cernicharo 1994, APJ 430,L125) at IRAM 30m (HPBW ~25") is 0.27K. If the line is of the simlar intensity in the dense core of RN88 and RN122 the expected line in a 1" ALMA beam will be detected with a good S/N.
We have no estimate for the intensities of other lines which are to observed bsides CS (2-1) and their possible detection will be a bonus. The 85GHz continuum is necessry because of ALMA calibraton.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our previous observations and modelling of very tiny molecular clouds, called globulettes, that reside in HII regions surrounding young stellar clusters, open a number of questions regarding their nature and fate. Why do most objects lack tails and bright Halpha-emitting rims? How long can they survive in the hot nebular gas and UV radiation field? Are they gravitationally unstable to form free-floating planetary mass objects and low-mass brown dwarfs to be ejected into interstellar space? Our modelling suggests that globulettes may have a complex structure with a dense, cold core surrounded by thinner gas but enclosed by an outer dense and warm shell. Only with ALMA we can resolve the internal structure of globulettes for the first time. We have selected two representative globulettes in the Rosette Nebula for closer inspection.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
University College London, London, University of
